Hi,

=C2=A0 Simple, clean experiment, with sharp results, congrats on that,=
 definitely
a step forward ! Of course, it begs for more questions. I would=
 love to hear
you on such (fairly open) questions

=C2=A0 =C2=A01) Do you t=
hink that selection pressure for low connectivity is sufficient in
itself t=
o evolve large coherent networks, or is it just a piece of the puzzle ?
=C2=
=A0 =C2=A02) Do you see your work as an indication that any approach biased=
 to low
connectivity would reproduce the result ? Or does the way you guys =
enforced
this bias matters ?

To me=C2=A0
1) =3D> Part of the puzzle. Shoul=
d see how well it scales for increasingly
complex task, when the connection=
 graph gets bigger. A randomized=C2=A0
search process=C2=A0on large graph s=
ounds not so efficient, need something to guide it.
I advocate construction=
 process that have a feedback from what the neuron=C2=A0
network is computi=
ng. Don't know how to do it without creepling computational
cost tho...
2) =
=3D> I guess that the bias alone is enough, the way to introduce it might
n=
ot be such a big deal.=C2=A0

Again, great work, very helpful contribution =
:)

Alex
=C2=A0
Dr. Devert Alexandre
Researcher at the Nature Inspired Comp=
utation and Applications Laboratory (NICAL)
Lecturer at School Of Software =
Engineering of USTC

 From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>
To: neat users gro=
up group <neat@yahoogroups.com> 
Cc: Jean-Baptiste Mouret <mouret@...=
.fr>; Hod Lipson <hod.lipson@...> 
Sent: Thursday, February 7, 2013=
 1:57 AM
Subject: [neat] New paper on why modules evolve, and how to evolve=
 modular artificial neural networks
 

=C2=A0 
Hello all,

I'm extremely pl=
eased to announce a new paper on a subject that many--including myself--thi=
nk is critical to making significant progress in our field: the evolution o=
f modularity.=C2=A0

Jean-Baptiste Mouret, Hod Lipson and I have a new pape=
r that=C2=A0

1) sheds light on why modularity may evolve in biological net=
works (e.g. neural, genetic, metabolic, protein-protein, etc.)

2) provides=
 a simple technique for evolving neural networks that are modular and have =
increased evolvability, in that they adapt faster to new environments. The =
modules that formed solved subproblems in the domain.=C2=A0
Cite:=C2=A0Clun=
e J, Mouret J-B, Lipson H (2013) The evolutionary origins of modularity. Pr=
oceedings of the Royal Society B. 280: 20122863.=C2=A0http://dx.doi.org/10.=
1098/rspb.2012.2863=C2=A0(pdf)

Abstract: A central biological question is =
how natural organisms are so evolvable (capable of quickly adapting to new =
environments). A key driver of evolvability is the widespread modularity of=
 biological networks=E2=80=94their organization as functional, sparsely con=
nected subunits=E2=80=94but there is no consensus regarding why modularity =
itself evolved. Although most hypotheses assume indirect selection for evol=
vability, here we demonstrate that the ubiquitous, direct selection pressur=
e to reduce the cost of connections between network nodes causes the emerge=
nce of modular networks. Computational evolution experiments with selection=
 pressures to maximize network performance and minimize connection costs yi=
eld networks that are significantly more modular and more evolvable than co=
ntrol experiments that only select for performance. These results will cata=
lyse research in numerous disciplines, such as neuroscience and genetics, a=
nd enhance our ability to harness
 evolution for engineering purposes.

Vid=
eo:=C2=A0http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=3Dplayer_embedded&v=3DSG4_aW8=
LMng

There has been some nice coverage of this work in the popular press, =
in case you are interested:
National Geographic:=C2=A0http://phenomena.nati=
onalgeographic.com/2013/01/30/the-parts-of-life/MIT's Technology Review:=C2=
=A0http://www.technologyreview.com/view/428504/computer-scientists-reproduc=
e-the-evolution-of-evolvability/=C2=A0Fast Company:=C2=A0http://www.fastcom=
pany.com/3005313/evolved-brains-robots-creep-closer-animal-learningCornell =
Chronicle:=C2=A0http://www.news.cornell.edu/stories/Jan13/modNetwork.htmlSc=
ienceDaily:=C2=A0http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2013/01/130130082300.=
htm

Please let me know what you think and if you have any questions. I hop=
e this work will help our field move forward!




Best regards,
Jeff Clune
=

Assistant Professor
Computer Science
University of Wyoming
jclune@...=

jeffclune.com

se:separate;"><div>Hello all,</div><div><br></div><div>I'm extremely please=
d to announce a new paper on a subject that many--including myself--think i=
s critical to making significant progress in our field: the evolution of mo=
dularity. </div><div><br></div><div>Jean-Baptiste Mouret, Hod Lipson a=
nd I have a new paper that </div><div><br></div><div>1) sheds light on=
 why modularity may evolve in biological networks (e.g. neural, genetic, me=
tabolic, protein-protein, etc.)</div><div><br></div><div>2) provides a simp=
le technique for evolving neural networks that are modular and have increas=
ed evolvability, in that they adapt faster to new environments. The modules=
 that formed solved subproblems in the domain. </div><div><br></div>Ci=
te: Clune J, Mouret J-B, Lipson H (2013) The evolutionary origins of m=
odularity. Proceedings of the Royal Society B. 280:
 20122863. <a rel=
=3D"nofollow" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"http://dx.doi.org/10.1098/rspb.2012=
.2863"><span style=3D"color:rgb(0, 102, 204);">http://dx.doi.org/10.1098/rs=
pb.2012.2863</span></a> (<a rel=3D"nofollow" target=3D"_blank" href=3D=

rity-RoyalSociety.pdf"><span style=3D"color:rgb(0, 102, 204);">pdf</span></=
a>)<div style=3D"color:rgb(24, 24, 24);"><br></div><div style=3D"color:rgb(=

sms are so evolvable (capable of quickly adapting to new environments). A k=
ey driver of evolvability is the widespread modularity of biological networ=
ks=E2=80=94their organization as functional, sparsely connected subunits=E2=
=80=94but there is no consensus regarding why modularity itself evolved. Al=
though most hypotheses assume indirect selection for evolvability, here we =
demonstrate that the ubiquitous, direct selection pressure to reduce the co=
st
 of connections between network nodes causes the emergence of modular ne=
tworks. Computational evolution experiments with selection pressures to max=
imize network performance and minimize connection costs yield networks that=
 are significantly more modular and more evolvable than control experiments=

numerous disciplines, such as neuroscience and genetics, and enhance our ab=
ility to harness evolution for engineering purposes.</div><div><br></div><d=
